Common Issues

Why People Leave AT&T

Expensive Monthly Bills

AT&T's unlimited plans start at $65/month and can exceed $85/month with fees and taxes.

Long-Term Contracts

Many customers are locked into 2-year agreements with early termination fees up to $325.

Credit Check Required

AT&T runs a hard credit check that can impact your credit score and may result in deposit requirements.

Hidden Fees

Activation fees, upgrade fees, and administrative charges add up quickly on your monthly bill.

FAQ

Switching from AT&T

Common questions about making the switch

Yes! You can port your existing AT&T phone number to any alternative carrier. The process typically takes a few minutes to a few hours. Make sure you don't cancel your AT&T service before initiating the port, as you'll need your account active to transfer the number.

Most AT&T phones are compatible with AT&T MVNOs like Vouch Mobile since they use the same network. For carriers on different networks (T-Mobile, Verizon), your phone needs to be unlocked and support their bands. AT&T will unlock your phone for free if it's paid off and you've had it for at least 60 days.

If you're under contract, you may face early termination fees (up to $325). However, you can avoid this by: paying off your device balance, waiting until your contract ends, or switching to a no-contract carrier like Vouch Mobile after your current term. AT&T no longer offers traditional 2-year contracts on most plans.

For identical coverage, choose an AT&T MVNO like Vouch Mobile or Cricket Wireless - they use the exact same towers. Vouch Mobile offers the best value at $30/month with no credit check, while Cricket has physical stores. If you're in urban areas, T-Mobile or Verizon MVNOs are also excellent options.

Not if you choose an AT&T MVNO! Carriers like Vouch Mobile use AT&T's same towers and network infrastructure, so you get identical coverage. The only difference is you pay less. For non-AT&T alternatives, coverage depends on that network's strength in your area.
